title: Debugging - Subarray Sum
problem_statement:
Debugging - Subarray Sum

Max. score: 50.00

You are given a code for the following problem statement in the SubarraySum function. However, the solution fails the test cases because there are bugs in the code. Your task is to find and fix all the bugs so that it passes all the test cases.

Statement

You are given the following:

  • A 1D array A of size N
  • A 1D array B of size M

Another 2D array H is created of size N × M where each element in H is described as:

Hij = Ai × Bj for 1 ≤ i ≤ N and 1 ≤ j ≤ M

Task

Determine the maximum non-empty subarray sum in the array H.

Notes

  • A 2-D subarray is defined as contiguous elements in an array such that all the elements can be enclosed in a rectangle and no elements are missing from that rectangle. For example, if
    S = [1 2 3] [4 5 6] [7 8 9]
    then [1, 2, 4, 5] and [8, 9] are subarrays while [1, 3, 4, 6] and [1, 2, 4] are not.
  • 1-based indexing is followed.

Function Description

Complete the function SubarraySum. The function takes the following 4 parameters and returns the maximum sum in the subarray H:

  • N: Represents the size of array A
  • A: Represents the elements in array A
  • M: Represents the size of array B
  • B: Represents the elements in array B

Input Format

This is the input format that you must use to provide custom input (available above the Compile and Test button).

  • The first line contains T, denoting the number of test cases. T also specifies the number of times you have to run the SubarraySum function on a different set of inputs.
  • For each test case:
    • The first line contains N, denoting the size of array A
    • The second line contains N space-separated integers denoting elements of array A
    • The next line contains M denoting the size of array B
    • The next line contains M space-separated integers denoting elements of array B

Output Format

For each test case, print the maximum subarray sum in a new line.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ T ≤ 10
  • 1 ≤ N, M ≤ 105
  • -104 ≤ Ai ≤ 104 for i ∈ [1, N]
  • -104 ≤ Bj ≤ 104 for j ∈ [1, M]

Examples

2
3
2 -1 2
4
-1 3 -1 3
2
2 3
1
-1
15
-2

For the first test case:

  • N = 3
  • A = [2, -1, 2]
  • M = 4
  • B = [-1, 3, -1, 3]

The H constructed using H[i,j] = A_i times B_j will look like:

-2  6  -2  6
 1  -3  1  -3
-2  6  -2  6

You can choose the subarray with elements [6, -2, 6, -3, 1, -3, 6, -2, 6].

Thus, the maximum subarray sum is 15.

For the second test case:

  • N = 2
  • A = [2, 3]
  • M = 1
  • B = [-1]

You can choose the subarray [-2].

Thus, the maximum subarray sum is -2.

Limits

  • Time Limit: 10.0 sec(s) for each input file
  • Memory Limit: 256 MB
  • Source Limit: 1024 KB

title: Two Groups
problem_statement:
Two Groups

Given N student and M enemy relations. You need to divide these N students into 2 groups of equal sizes S such that no two students with direct enemy relations are in the same group. You need to maximize the value of S. Also, it is guaranteed that no student will have enemy relations with more than 2 students.

Notes:

  • S is the number of students in a single group.
  • Both groups should have the same number of students i.e. S.

Function Description

Complete the solve function. This function takes the following 3 parameters and returns the answer:

  • N: Represents a number of students
  • M: Represents the number of enemy relations
  • enemy: Represents the enemy relation

Input Format for Custom Testing

Use this input format if you are testing against custom input or writing code in a language where we don\'t provide boilerplate code.

  • The first line contains an integer N.
  • The second line contains an integer M.
  • The next M lines contains two space-separated integers, u and v, representing the enemy relation between u and v.

Output Format

Print the maximum possible value of S.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ M < N ≤ 5 × 105
  • 1 ≤ u,v ≤ N

Sample Test Case

Input:
6
4
1 2
2 4
1 5
6 3
Output:
3

Explanation

Given:

  • N = 6
  • M = 4
  • enemy = [(1, 2), (2, 4), (1, 5), (6, 3)]

Approach:

  • You can form two groups in the following way:
    • 1st group = [1, 4, 6]
    • 2nd group = [2, 5, 3]
  • You can see no direct enemies are in the same group and hence the maximum possible value of S=3

Limits

  • Time Limit: 2.0 sec(s) for each input file
  • Memory Limit: 256 MB
  • Source Limit: 1024 KB

Scoring

Score is assigned if any testcase passes

Allowed Languages

Bash, C, C++17, Clojure, C#, D, Erlang, F#, Go, Groovy, Haskell, Java 8, Java 14, JavaScript(Node.js), Julia, Kotlin, Lisp (SBCL), Lua, Objective-C, OCaml, Octave, Pascal, Perl, PHP, Python, Python 3, Python 3.8, Racket, Ruby, Rust, Scala, Swift, TypeScript, Visual Basic
